jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

6FB5E5725FAC486FBCDC737EC0C6EA8F.description: Use stories as an inspiration for dramatic expression

1182FBA5A633488B8E42A9CE4A56C069.description: Explore pantomime and mime as dramatic forms

DCF35835C6E24111A7FC93D4BF6DC080.description: Create dramatizations based on comedy and tragedy

24D4846BAA8F48378B554D36DBD57F2E.description: Demonstrate how to follow artistic protocols and etiquette in various drama experiences.

9FC9EFFF3A4047CEBCB95436623C33B9.description: Examine how drama can be used to express topics or themes that are important to individuals or cultures

5EA05C6907C1487B8237E101CAB4CB5E.description: Express how drama is valued in one's life and culture

22EB7AC3042049C9AF8AA090A689D608.description: Drama in New France reflected a combination of culture and traditions that served different purposes for the people who lived there

E64E9CE07C2D454E906DCE016443C7BD.description: The cultures of ancient Rome had an influence on modern-day drama and theatre

057E28A15DBD456B816944739F8BD393.description: Drama in ancient Rome reflected cultural beliefs and history

F7A87A17AF2346B38876314EA2D5A009.description: An artistic community is a venue for artistic expression within various cultures

2B32E2B5EFB94303B3AA4E2606D51A53.description: Drama was valued differently across cultures throughout history.

4C22FEE88E4643288367B1FD14031E2A.description: Theatre in New France was primarily performed by community members to provide entertainment and to celebrate the establishment of the French community

3E58B8CBB2E448EABACBC45DFE730FD0.description: The performance of The Theatre of Neptune took place on barges and canoes in Port Royal, and depicted French exploration and expeditions to Acadia

0BC651DEBDE8416D99C6FE4EDCFC90B0.description: The Theatre of Neptune, by Marc Lescarbot in 1606, is considered one of Canada's first formal European plays that incorporated music, including trumpets, cannons, and choral singing.

CD280914C2154A1EB5EA57346BB9330A.description: Protocols related to how or with whom stories are shared were part of First Nations culture in New France and continue to hold significant importance today.

BEFFF2E1F4D549C097248306A253B737.description: First Nations storytelling in New France reflected traditions and beliefs that continue to be honoured and celebrated today by First Nations, Metis, and Inuit

481172F25A864E1E8A04CB1A8674D035.description: Storytelling and ceremony were significant aspects of First Nations culture for hundreds of years before the arrival of the Europeans

28A4C94E435F489F819D81DC3DE6DD10.description: Mime emerged during Roman theatre as a way to interact with the chorus using dance and gestures.

6EB47C99C78D44A08E2C8784F2DB74DC.description: Roman pantomime is a dramatic story told without words and characterized by the use of gestures, beautiful costumes, and masks

3E8C18C944224AED8C6BDEBB440BE762.description: In ancient Rome, tragedies became less popular as people enjoyed and preferred the entertainment value of a comedy

72D822D5A10043A1B88262187F36ADE3.description: A stock character represents a certain type of person or stereotype, such as a brave hero or a clumsy waiter

E8C75724A8014C8C8DF9086D112CA15D.description: Roman theatre was well known for using stock characters and comedy, which led to the later development of clowning

96F64A1056EC4241AD3EAF590A4F2F3E.description: Theatre in the round was a type of staging used in Greek and Roman theatre that provided enhanced sound and sightlines for an audience, as seen in the Colosseum

4C5DA81DF1CE4B23873E3D7D61820714.description: Nearly all Roman plays, including the costumes used, were imitations or similar representations of Greek comedies and tragedies

289674EFE80F46A0AC6FA6DB5405550B.description: Stories about gods and goddesses (mythology) in ancient Rome were commonly expressed through drama

D46A1F650C914D4A94994FB9497DF215.description: Theatre and drama in ancient Rome was valued for its ability to entertain

F9D3C6D2577F46BCB3C0BCFDC78C03B8.description: Dramatic forms that originated from various cultures in the past continue to be used and valued today.

3FF5158D7AD14E0885B5F7E0C428DFC4.description: The topics or themes expressed through drama may have a particular significance to the culture, time, and place in which they are expressed.

F60079BD67DB4F50BD040880B993DEB7.description: Artistic protocols and etiquette may change based on the community, culture, presentation, and location of a performance

9A3C0FF94CB94264BDCF61D3FE92C23F.description: Using vocabulary related to drama can contribute to discussions about drama.

830901C060C642189122FD29404D2534.description: From historical times to today, cultures may have valued drama for cultural expression, entertainment, and education

B19518224DC54356A2463D888355B53B.description: Students relate how cultures of the past and present contribute to dramatic expression

E04F726C30CE44C6871CB4828F2F4B3B.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in drama can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great dramatic works, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

F4857C7E64C240B3ADCD67B89D66CE12.description: Rehearse dramatizations before performing for an audience

306416A674404A4680919314CEA8E729.description: Consider feedback from an audience to refine a message

685C51FC4A044FBEABE93437DD442091.description: Create a dramatization that communicates a message that is based on a theme or subject.

2A12872452224A159B931A7BB2AEB253.description: Discuss how a message in drama can evoke a response from an audience

15564C6B58E04F55986CBA3A56B8459A.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in drama

57AEA62FA5CC4D47AAE54EE405724326.description: Demonstrate how a single message can be expressed in many different ways

ECD0F072308642068FD89C517919C21D.description: Identify when costumes or props are helping or hindering dramatic expression

EDE3283695844EACBA8813E8B4EFC4A6.description: Experiment with costumes and props as a way to enhance communication of a message

E362988CE08A43B59A8313306230E8F2.description: Experiment with various ways to use the voice to perform a message in and out of character

A432F1480EC246799DB5D834655C1520.description: Explain the reason for making specific artistic choices.

78B82104A85D401FB32DD800F689913E.description: Make informed artistic choices to share a message through drama

7A40B6CAFA454E6384F6D47C7DDC70CE.description: Messages can represent what an artist means to communicate through dramatizations

43F8407C6C784ECEA558E561852A80DA.description: An audience receives and interprets messages communicated through dramatic expression

C2CFF29A4A0F40FC996FFFA76D812A4D.description: A message is at the centre of communication in drama

FD239B667AB042C7ACD10365CF44C6A5.description: A single message can be expressed in numerous ways by applying artistic choices

B5EC758466C246D084D29BEBE7DB65CA.description: Artists intentionally choose specific ways to effectively share a message

5D8175ECD8FA4BB088D65B19625CA902.description: Circle formations are found in drama and storytelling across various cultures of the world

75C46F75E828470FBB82783A64F32820.description: The circle is a symbol that can communicate messages in drama, including unity

B956DBFCE5464F5CBE9518A75C2E5EA8.description: Messages expressed through drama are clear when rehearsed and performed with energy, appropriate volume, and expressivity

438406AF350249F8859C9A2AB075A048.description: A performer's message can be refined for future performances when feedback is considered

2769779C537E4275B54839F497B8D0CE.description: A message in drama can be developed and clarified with the help of creative processes, including generating ideas problem solving reflection giving and receiving feedback refinement rehearsal

B5D5877B41B2485BB93E0BA4B89FF93C.description: A message in drama can represent a variety of themes or subjects, including ideas, culture, and events

24E23C7108B544E4AFA38B2AC8867B91.description: Messages can evoke different responses from an audience based on their beliefs, preferences, and feelings

09B008A9A3BE4AF696DA93CCBD9386A1.description: Messages can be created for an intended audience and may have topics or themes that can be sensitive to some viewers

55A8CC07BFFB4F0685BECEFBD7838E23.description: Speaking clearly and with ease contributes to effectively sharing a message

032EA355104843888F9195656C6576A7.description: Costumes and props can contribute to the creation of a message when used with intention

7EAD4163123F4A00B14855A75DFC7135.description: A character's message can be communicated through artistic choices related to the voice and the body

B343A7C12FAA4713BF5C9018F1E1C776.description: A message can be structured using dramatic forms

D35B7BDF9DE440119DBC8B42E04EA4EB.description: Messages in drama can be created by imagination.

FF8F40508944427EAD34BF2601B856AF.description: Students interpret how the communication of a message can be influenced by artistic choice in drama.

C1DFFE112D8B4473B321C604D9A76493.description: Creating and Presenting: Ideas can be represented dramatically through artworks that draw upon foundational knowledge

CC7B264F81A248949DE0AB454E0EC252.description: Extend speaking skills to include appropriate volume, energy, and expressivity

6EA82176216A4249B2BA9D896B1C083E.description: Participate in drama activities that prepare the body and voice for expression

35EBB455995B4E688D9CDB873DE53E05.description: Experiment with voice to convey a character.

C1C2E89247914F298381E9C1B71ABC3A.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of body actions in the representation of character

C9E49286E32844AFA38883CA7E8EB669.description: Explore how changing body actions can communicate character, including feelings

C5C36383934F40B896D38014DFC74F59.description: Consider how personal characteristics can contribute to character development.

379EFFDB86D4472F93D9F1676521B474.description: Discuss how various dramatic forms can be used to tell a story

9D34DF63D038450CBC601D2DBEE717A9.description: Demonstrate how various dramatic forms can support expression

56443AFC852E4C56943FB32948842C04.description: Explore how different body movements can communicate meaning

FA5BD2CC51FC4A4F84CFCF7A6B926C43.description: A performer's personal characteristics can be used as a starting point for character development

78611EAEE2FA419394531503B50B66EC.description: Character can be developed through the body

B9DD07B53C564DAE98F594AEDCF4A39A.description: The body is dynamic and can be used to express meaning.

ACB3E47766414AA08F057164FD495E30.description: Warm-up activities for the body and voice can contribute to dramatic expression

749DF2869949457D8CA2B54070685E0E.description: Choral speech as a dramatic form can support group expression, including speaking clearly speaking with ease learning to articulate enjoyment of literature exploring the flexibility of the voice

B029E63AAE064B358890C4D0D0C7CB32.description: Character development can be supported by other characters

236403FC976645EA855A28DEF0359255.description: Role play can support the exploration of a character

46060FF5B6B54E76B0E524AF3C3F0DB5.description: The voice is part of the body and can be used to develop a character

D023EA0096F24F169BE135F2BB69C345.description: Body actions can convey character through facial expressions, gestures, and body movements

AD7B50EB319C4825BAEAA2B8CE1AFD25.description: Physical theatre is a dramatic form that uses body movements to tell a story.

94866B1F71994D31B4C2FBE40DAE1074.description: Mime is a dramatic form that uses specific movements to communicate non-verbally

396425F82C7D4621A10164135E526E32.description: Individuals express meaning with the body in various ways.

EB886C6C1BFF410E9E54A8750878C7EC.description: The body can represent the material world through drama, including animals, objects, and the environment

4BF754C9C5E54E7595EB12607DFEB31E.description: Students analyze how the body can portray character in a variety of dramatic contexts.

C59CCB773C0A4A60BE9524C4C775FC14.description: Foundational Elements: Drama literacy is developed through knowledge and application of dramatic processes.
